findings.explanation: Storm surge is a critical threat associated with hurricanes, often causing more fatalities than wind. The severity of storm surge is influenced by several factors, including hurricane intensity, size, speed, and track, as well as the ocean bathymetry (shape of the ocean floor). Stronger hurricanes with higher winds can push more water towards the shore, resulting in a more severe storm surge. Larger hurricanes with a bigger diameter of strong winds can also blow more water towards the coast, leading to a more extensive storm surge. Slow-moving hurricanes can batter the coastline for hours, causing the storm surge to move farther inland. Additionally, the location of the hurricane's eye relative to the coastline can significantly impact the severity and location of the storm surge. The shape of the ocean floor can also influence how easily water moves inland and the resulting storm surge impacts. [Data: Relationships (61, 157, 158, 159, 160, 161)]
